Literature Review: The study of human object vision has evolved significantly over the years, transitioning from classic theories focused primarily on object recognition to a more nuanced understanding that encompasses a wide range of behavioral goals. This literature review delves into the complexities of object vision, highlighting the advancements in behavioral paradigms, neuroscientific methods, and computational modeling that have contributed to our current understanding. The traditional view of object vision as a process centered around object recognition has been challenged by recent findings that suggest a more complex, multidimensional representational space underlies our visual perception of objects. This shift in perspective is largely attributed to the integration of insights from deep convolutional neural networks (DCNNs), which have provided a computational framework for understanding the hierarchical processing of visual information in the brain. Research by DiCarlo et al. (2012) has demonstrated that DCNNs can mimic the object recognition capabilities of the human visual system, suggesting that similar principles of hierarchical processing may be at play. However, the application of DCNNs to the study of object vision has also revealed the limitations of focusing solely on object recognition. Studies by Kriegeskorte (2015) and others have shown that the representational spaces in both the brain and DCNNs are highly multidimensional, reflecting not just the identity of objects but also their attributes, context, and the tasks associated with them. This multidimensionality suggests that object vision is deeply intertwined with a broader range of behavioral goals, challenging the notion of core object recognition as the primary function of the visual system. Neuroscientific methods, such as functional MRI (fMRI), have further illuminated the complexity of object representations in the visual cortex. Research by Grill-Spector and Weiner (2014) has identified multiple regions within the visual cortex that are specialized for processing different aspects of objects, from their basic features to their semantic categories. This specialization indicates that object vision involves a distributed network of brain regions, each contributing to different dimensions of object representation. Behavioral paradigms have also evolved to capture the full repertoire of human visual behavior, moving beyond simple recognition tasks to include tasks that require the integration of visual information with action, memory, and decision-making. Studies by Peelen and Kastner (2014) have shown that the visual system is highly adaptable, with object representations being dynamically shaped by the current behavioral goals of the observer. This adaptability underscores the importance of considering the full range of human behavior in understanding object vision. In conclusion, the field of human object vision has moved beyond the simplicity of classic theories to embrace a more complex view that recognizes the multidimensional nature of object representations and their integration with a wide range of behavioral goals. This shift has been facilitated by advancements in behavioral paradigms, neuroscientific methods, and computational modeling, particularly the insights gained from DCNNs. As we continue to explore the complexities of object vision, it becomes increasingly clear that understanding human visual perception requires a holistic approach that considers the diverse functions of the visual system in supporting human behavior.
